'''Operation Harness''' was a series of secret [[biological warfare]] trials carried out by the government of the United Kingdom in the Caribbean in the 1940s.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/politics/526870.stm|title=Germ warfare fiasco revealed|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=19 November 1999|accessdate=6 October 2013}}</ref> Animals were exposed to [[anthrax]] and [[brucella]] bacteria on dinghys offshore but the results were found meaningless.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/>
The operation did not go well, for several reasons. The sea was rougher than expected, making it impossible for the dinghies to be picked up by craft converted for the operation.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/> This meant the tests were carried out just off the shore of an island, endangering inhabitants.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/> Protective suits were found to be so heavy that those using them had to undergo a lengthy acclimatisation process to avoid heat exhaustion.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/>
Sampling equipment was accidentally activated by local radio signals and conditions at sea made it impossible to accurately measure the amount of bacteria in the atmosphere.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/>
500 of 600 [[sheep]] were found to be unsuitable and were shot.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/> [[Guinea pig]]s were found to be "disastrous".<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/> 234 [[rhesus macaque]]s had to be treated for pneumonia before being used.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/>
The official report found that the techniques used were overcomplicated, and said that it was "uncommonly lucky" that only one of the staff was infected.<ref name=bbc-operation-harness/>
